In the final Group A match, India takes on New Zealand on March 2. The IND vs NZ CT Match will be played at the Dubai International Cricket Stadium in Dubai, and begin at 2:30 Indian Standard Time (IST). The official broadcast partners of ICC Champions Trophy 2025 are JioStar Network which will provide live telecast viewing options of the India vs New Zealand CT match on Star Sports 1, Star Sports 1 Hindi, Star Sports 2, and Sports TV Channels in India. Fans can switch to online live streaming viewing options of IND vs NZ CT 2025 on JioHotstar app and website, which will be free of cost. text:
You‚Äôre reading an excerpt from the WorldView newsletter. Sign up to get the rest free, including news from around the globe and interesting ideas and opinions to know, sent to your inbox on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. It was the outburst that could be a hinge point of history. We‚Äôre still gauging the smoldering fallout of the Oval Office clash on Friday that saw President Donald Trump and Vice President JD Vance angrily confront Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. What had started out as a set-piece marking a deal over Ukraine‚Äôs mineral wealth that would tighten Trump‚Äôs support for Kyiv in potential negotiations with Russia turned into a debacle, as Trump and Vance berated Zelensky over his perceived weak bargaining position and supposed lack of gratitude for U.S. assistance.

The deal was called off and the Ukrainian delegation left the White House early. Zelensky later flew to Europe, where rattled leaders on the continent rallied around him. In Washington, Trump loyalists ‚Äî Republican lawmakers and right-wing media ‚Äî cheered the public airing of grievances and denounced Zelensky. The sticking point in the spat seemed the Ukrainian president‚Äôs desire for clear U.S. security guarantees that would help deter Russia, which launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, from violating a future ceasefire.

Advertisement

Those guarantees are not forthcoming from Trump, whose administration has already sought to initiate a thaw with the Kremlin and voted against a U.N. resolution last week that called out Russian aggression in Ukraine. ‚ÄúTime is not on your side on the battlefield,‚Äù said White House national security adviser Michael Waltz, recounting to reporters what he told Zelensky in the aftermath of the Oval Office blowup. ‚ÄúTime is not on your side in terms of the world situation and most importantly, U.S. aid and the taxpayers, tolerance is not unlimited.‚Äù

The argument, my colleagues noted, has ‚Äúlaid bare the deepening rift between Europe and the Trump administration and Republican Party, jeopardizing U.S. aid for Ukraine, the end of war in Europe, and the prospect of a renewed relationship between‚Äù Trump and Zelensky.

President Donald Trump, Vice President JD Vance and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky engaged in an argument about the Russia- Ukraine war on Feb. 28. (Video: The Washington Post, Photo: Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post)

And it goes deeper than that. Under the previous Biden administration, the war in Ukraine was a galvanizing moment for what can be described as the geopolitical ‚ÄúWest‚Äù ‚Äî the nations and institutions that have shaped the transatlantic alliance for decades. The United States surged aid to Ukraine‚Äôs defense, but also helped coordinate Europe‚Äôs response. NATO bolstered its capabilities and expanded its membership. The European Union welcomed millions of Ukrainian refugees and mustered vast sums in financial aid for Kyiv, as Western leaders championed their shared values in the defense of Ukraine‚Äôs sovereignty and embattled democracy.

Advertisement

That support may continue, but possibly without Trump, who has never placed much stock in the United States‚Äô traditional partnerships. He casts the European Union as a threat to American interests and NATO as a club of delinquent junior partners. ‚ÄúToday, it became clear that the free world needs a new leader,‚Äù Kaja Kallas, the European Union‚Äôs top diplomat and a former Estonian prime minister, said Friday. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs up to us, Europeans, to take this challenge.‚Äù

‚ÄúNow is the moment to stay calm, but not carry on,‚Äù Camille Grand, a distinguished policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations and former top NATO official, wrote on social media. ‚ÄúThe US Ally has now officially decided to take a stance inconsistent with our traditionally shared interests and values. This might be temporary or lasting but this will have profound and enduring consequences.‚Äù

In Moscow, this apparent rupture is welcome. Speaking to reporters over the weekend, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov noted the ‚Äúrapidly changing [U.S.] foreign policy configurations‚Äù under Trump, who, while extending an olive branch to Russia, has also set about bullying U.S. neighbors and preparing a new trade war with Europe. The dramatic shift, Peskov added, ‚Äúlargely coincides with our vision.‚Äù

During a Fox News interview on Feb. 28, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky showed appreciation, but denied the need to apologize to President Donald Trump. (Video: Fox News)

For Ukraine, the news is grim. Zelensky may struggle to redeem himself in the eyes of Trump, who expected the Ukrainian leader to play the role of supplicant in a grand diplomatic bargain arranged over his head. As European leaders called for calm, analysts speculated an irked Trump could suspend military transfers to Ukraine. A shortfall in munitions for critical U.S.-made air defense systems, among other armaments, would be disastrous for a country that faces constant Russian bombardments and airstrikes.

Advertisement

European countries, including major powers like Britain and Germany, are seeking to fast-track increases in defense spending to help Ukraine. On Sunday, as he hosted Zelensky and other leaders on the continent, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer ‚Äúcalled on other European governments to grow their militaries and to join a ‚Äòcoalition of the willing‚Äô in taking up the slack in Ukraine,‚Äù my colleagues reported.

But there may be much more slack to take up if the Trump administration makes good on its longer-term plans to draw down U.S. forces in Europe as part of a broader strategic pivot to the Indo-Pacific. ‚ÄúI just worry that, given, frankly, President Trump‚Äôs mercurial nature,‚Äù Nigel Gould-Davies, a former British diplomat and senior fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, told my colleagues, ‚Äúhow much confidence really can Europe have in any degree of American protection and defense.‚Äù

Trump and Vance may delight in shocking Europe, but their counterparts across the pond are coming to terms with the collapse of a united West. ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs rhetoric melds with [Russian President Vladimir] Putin‚Äôs,‚Äù wrote Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon. ‚ÄúIn less than two weeks, concessions to Moscow have piled up. Even if they had already been in the pipeline since Joe Biden‚Äôs administration: No Ukraine in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO); no NATO forces to monitor a possible ceasefire; necessary territorial concessions from Kyiv.‚Äù

Advertisement

Trump‚Äôs wrecking ball approach to diplomacy offers rich opportunities for others. ‚ÄúChina is certainly happy to see the way things are unfolding,‚Äù said Wen-Ti Sung, a lecturer at the Australian National University‚Äôs College of Asia and the Pacific, to the Australian Financial Review, a daily newspaper. ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs firing on all cylinders, against friends and foes alike diplomatically, is rapidly humanizing China‚Äôs own wolf warrior diplomacy.‚Äù

The irony, noted some analysts, is that the Western alliance system has been a major bulwark in the United States‚Äô ability to project global power for decades. Trump, in his pursuit of a narrower vision of American interests and seeming alignment with strongmen elsewhere, is turning an epochal page.
title: Trump-Zelensky meeting: The end of the geopolitical ‚ÄòWest‚Äô

'Emilia P√©rez' actress Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n appears at the Oscars despite backlash

toggle caption Chris Pizzello/AP

Emilia P√©rez actress Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n appeared at the Oscars on Sunday night ‚Äî a surprise for many following backlash to the actress' tweets in recent weeks.

In late January, offensive social media posts from the best actress Oscar nominee recirculated online. The posts vilified Muslims, attacked China in the context of COVID-19 and commented on the 2020 murder of George Floyd, calling him a "drug addicted swindler."

Though she apologized for the tweets , Gasc√≥n fiercely defended herself, reiterating, "I am not a racist."

Netflix did not respond to NPR's request for comment in February about whether or not the actress was still involved in the streamer's Oscar campaign.

Sponsor Message

Emilia P√©rez is a musical about a trans cartel boss in Mexico. It led this year's Academy Award nominations with 13 nods, including Gasc√≥n's ‚Äî a historic first acting nomination for an openly trans actress.

The film itself has also been subject to scrutiny for its portrayal of Mexican culture and the trans experience. LGBTQ advocacy organization GLAAD has said that the film, despite its lead actress being transgender, is "not good trans representation."

Still, Gasc√≥n and the film were both celebrated when Emilia P√©rez first premiered at the 2024 Cannes Film Festival. Gasc√≥n received an Arco√≠ris award from the Spanish government, which recognizes people for "raising awareness, supporting and defending the rights of LGBTI people."
title: 'Emilia P√©rez' actress Karla Sof√≠a Gasc√≥n appears at the Oscars despite backlash
